workflow.name: Audit Confluence space permissions and public links for compliance
workflow.description:
## Audit permissions in Confluence to ensure compliance

This workflow scans selected **Confluence spaces** for **public exposure risks**, helping teams identify unintended access and potential data leakage.

### What it does
- Detects public exposure risks in Confluence spaces, including:
  - **Anonymous access permissions** at space level
  - Whether **public links are enabled**
  - Pages with **active or blocked public links**
- Uses **Confluence REST API v2** together with the **Atlassian GraphQL API**.
- Produces a consolidated per-space report containing:
  - Anonymous access permissions
  - Public link status
  - Pages with public links (title, status, URL, enabled-by user)
- Ideal for **security audits**, **compliance reviews**, and **data leakage prevention**.

### How it works
- The workflow starts via a **Manual Trigger**.
- A **Set Variables** node defines:
  - `atlassianDomain`
  - `spaceKeys` (comma-separated)
- **Get Spaces (v2)** retrieves matching spaces and splits them into individual items.
- For each space, three **GraphQL queries** run in parallel:
  - Retrieve **anonymous access permissions**
  - Check **public link feature status** at space level
  - Fetch **pages with public links** (ON / BLOCKED)
- Results from all three queries are merged and normalized into a single per-space report.

### Setup
- Configure the **Set Variables** node:
  - `atlassianDomain` ‚Üí your Confluence base URL  
  - `spaceKeys` ‚Üí comma-separated list (e.g. `ENG, HR`)
- Create an **HTTP Basic Auth** credential for Atlassian:
  - Email + API token
  - Assign it to all HTTP and GraphQL nodes
- Ensure the credential has permission to:
  - Read spaces
  - Read space permissions
  - Access GraphQL endpoints
- Execute the workflow manually to generate the report.

### Notes
- Uses the **Atlassian GraphQL API**, which exposes permission and public-link data not fully available via REST.
- Pages with blocked public links are included for visibility.
- The GraphQL page query fetches up to **250 pages per space**.

workflow.name: Audit permissions in Confluence to ensure compliance

parameters.content:
## Confluence API Reference
* [V2 Get Spaces](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/confluence/rest/v2/api-group-space/#api-spaces-get)

## Atlassian GraphQL API Reference
* [GraphQL API](https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/confluence/graphql/#overview)

nodes.name: Confluence - GQL Space Public Links Enabled
Confluence - GQL Space Pages with Public Link

parameters.query:
query PublicLinkPagesTablePublicLinksByCriteriaQuery(
  $spaceId: ID!
  $status: [PublicLinkStatus!]
  $after: String
  $title: String
  $type: [String]
  $first: Int = 25
  $orderBy: PublicLinksByCriteriaOrder = DATE_ENABLED
  $isAscending: Boolean = true
) {
  publicLinksByCriteria(
    spaceId: $spaceId
    status: $status
    after: $after
    first: $first
    orderBy: $orderBy
    isAscending: $isAscending
    title: $title
    type: $type
  ) {
    nodes {
      id
      status
      publicLinkUrlPath
      lastEnabledBy
      lastEnabledDate
      title
      type

      lastEnabledByUser {
        displayName
        permissionType
      }

    }
  }
}

nodes.name: Set Space Pages with Public Link

assignments.name: pagesWithPublicLink

parameters.content:
## Atlassian GraphQL
Checks for Anonymous access, public links enabled and pages with public links

### Notes
- Uses **Atlassian GraphQL API**
- Pages with blocked links are still included for visibility.
- Current GraphQL page query fetches up to **250 pages per space**.
- Need help? ‚úâÔ∏è **office@sus-tech.at**

## How it works
This workflow audits Confluence spaces for public exposure risks, focusing on anonymous access and public links. A **Set Variables** node defines the Atlassian domain and the list of space keys to evaluate.

Using the **Confluence API v2**, the workflow retrieves all matching spaces and processes them one by one. For each space, multiple checks run in parallel using GraphQL.

These queries detect:
  - **Anonymous access permissions** on spaces
  - Whether **public links are enabled** at space level
  - Pages with **active or blocked public links**


The results from all queries are combined into a single, structured output that highlights spaces and pages that may be publicly accessible. This makes it easier to review risks, confirm compliance or share findings with security and documentation owners.

## Setup steps
1. Open the **Set Variables** node and configure:
   - `atlassianDomain`: Your Confluence base URL  
   - `spaceKeys`: Comma-separated list of space keys (for example `ENG,HR`)  
2. Create an **HTTP Basic Auth** credential in n8n using your Atlassian email address and API token.
3. Assign this credential to all HTTP and GraphQL nodes in the workflow.
4. Verify the credential has permission to read spaces, space permissions and GraphQL endpoints.
5. (Optional) Extend the workflow with email, Slack, or CSV export nodes using the output.
